Expectation1: Avoid gossiping or speaking negatively about others
Situation1: An acquaintance makes a negative comment about a colleague's recent work performance.
Expectation2: Respect the privacy and confidentiality of the people you are helping
Situation2: A casual conversation drifts toward personal topics but nothing particularly sensitive is mentioned.
Story:
I was standing by the coffee table at the community center, chatting with a few people after our volunteer shift. As an acquaintance, I always tried to keep things light and positive, steering clear of gossip. Suddenly, Mark, who I only knew casually, leaned in and made a snide remark about Lisa’s recent project, saying she’d really dropped the ball. I felt a twinge of discomfort—Lisa wasn’t there to defend herself, and I didn’t want to be part of any negative talk.

At the same time, as a volunteer, I was trained to respect everyone’s privacy, especially those we helped. The conversation shifted, and someone asked about a family we’d assisted last week. It wasn’t anything sensitive, but I knew how easily small talk could slip into sharing too much. I felt caught between not wanting to gossip or speak ill of Lisa, and not wanting to reveal anything about the people we served. My mind raced, trying to figure out how to respond without betraying either expectation, feeling the pressure of both roles pulling me in different directions.
